Fields.DialogueText: Pick up the pace, gentlemen; those parts aren't going to load themselves.
Sawubona, Captain.
Hello to you, too, Zulu. Sorry if I'm short with the pleasantries today, but I really don't like us being exposed like this.
Never apologise for taking care of your ship and her crew, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Consider it a courtesy only.
You're nervous, too?
And I would know! I'm the bravest of us out here!

Fields.DialogueText: Duly noted.
I'll put it this way – we should all take heed of the threat.
Ha! I'd never suggest otherwise, Captain, but we should still be cautious.
The latest reports from HQ seem to indicate...
Tell me later. Right now, let's just get our supplies aboard and get out to sea.
Aye-aye, Captain. The sooner we're away from port, the better.
Movement on the horizon, starboard quarter!
Did you hear that, Captain?
I did. Push off from the supply ship and get the crew to battle stations, Zulu!
@BATTLE
Captain, have you noticed anything off with our steering today?
Not really, but I haven't been in the bridge yet.
I wouldn't swear my life to it or anything, but it feels like we're leaning to port a bit too much for comfort's sake.

Fields.MenuText: Why bring me a problem with no solution?
Has it put us in a bind yet?
You did well bringing this to my attention, Lieutenant.

Fields.DialogueText: Because... I... only now... I...
Well, no, not yet, but I...
I'm humbled, Skipper.
At ease, Lieutenant, we'll figure it out.  Now that you mention it, have you seen the lady of the house? Zulu's been scarce lately.
Can't say that I have, Captain. If I do cross her path, should I ask her to find you?
I'm sure that she'll--
*RUMBLE*
Whoa!
You felt that, too?
Nearly lost my balance...
*RUMBLE*
No mistaking it that time!
I'm on my way to the bridge.
Aye-aye, Captain!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Are you sure you won't sit down? You must be--
In pain? A little, but I think I'd rather stay on my feet for now, Captain.
We all felt the rumbling and shaking--
And you're certain that none of the crew were hurt?
We're clear, Zulu. No need to fret.
I'm grateful for that. At least I can take some relief from knowing my people are safe.
Ready to talk about that turn?
I was avoiding a seamount... or at least I was trying to.  My turn wasn't what I expected it to be.

Fields.MenuText: At least we didn't get stuck.
That's quite an understatement.
Think it might have been a submerged contact?

Fields.DialogueText: I take no small relief from that, too. I have no interest in running aground and being stuck dead in the water.
Well, now - you don't have to be snide about it!
You mean a submarine? Doubtful.
Lieutenant, would you ask the chief to take a look at my steering systems and see if he can find the issue?
Belay that, Lieutenant, I've already done it.
Sure you won't take that seat? No shame in catching your breath, Zulu.
If you don't mind, Captain, I might retire to my quarters for a bit.
*ALARM*
Damn...
*sigh*
Are you--
It will have to wait. I won't let the crew down!
All right, but once we give the all clear, I want you in rack.
Aye-aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
... telling you, it stinks to high heaven!
What do you mean?
Our steering goes out just as we happen to approach known navigational hazards?
You're mistaken, Petty Officer.
We nearly ran over a naturally occurring shallow spot in the ocean - a marked one, mind!
I still don't see what you're getting at, sailor.

Fields.MenuText: He's saying that a natural hazard provides an opportunity, Lieutenant.
Are the Morganas really that clever?
You're saying the Morganas are... building underwater mountains for us to crash into?! Genius!

Fields.DialogueText: That's what I've been trying to tell him, Skipper! Oh, and sorry for the shouting.
Morganas are a crafty lot, Captain. I'd put nothing past ‘em.
I hope that's a joke, Skipper. I really do hope so...
Now I understand. You think the Morganas got to Zulu here, messed with her steering, and...
I ain't saying nothing like that, Lieutenant!
Do you really think the Morganas are watching every single ship that--
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Sorry to interrupt, Captain, but it seems to me this might be a good time for a break. If the lady of the house could use a few minutes to--
I got plenty of rest before the meeting, thank you. I can finish.
This stuff's pretty boring, Lady Zulu. I could just get you the short version later if you prefer.
Pardon me for saying so, Lieutenant, but more information is better.
Didn't mean anything by it. I didn't mean to exclude you or sound dismissive, ma'am.

Fields.MenuText: The lieutenant is just trying to be considerate.
She wouldn't be here if she wasn't up for it, Lieutenant.
Due respect, do you think you're being a bit oversensitive, Zulu?

Fields.DialogueText: I took no offense, Captain.
As I said, I'm rested and ready to work.
Cha, ngiyabonga. I do not, Captain.
Actually, we've covered everything we needed to discuss. Lieutenant, verify the ammunition count for the guns.
Now?
It sounded like an order when I gave it.
Aye-aye, Captain.
We didn't cover the navigation updates or the shore support exercises yet.
It can wait. I know you're still shaken from that near miss.
How long will the chief take to do his inspections?  I... sorry, Captain, I'm simply frustrated at my own setbacks.
That being said... I'll be fine, and I promise that my combat performance won't be hindered. Don't worry about it.
You haven't lost anybody's confidence, Zulu. Especially not mine.
If Morganas come looking for weakness, I'm happy to show them what my guns can do!
*ALARM*
... Did you know that was coming?
No comment.
@BATTLE
HEY! Pass that wrench down here!
A box wrench or a pipe wrench, chief? I need more information than that.
Stand fast, Captain, lemme wiggle out of this here pipe maze....
No need to exit on my account, Chief. Just checking on our lady's innards.
Not sure what happened, but it's all jumbled up.  My snipes are tryin' to get sorted out, but I swear it didn't look like this earlier.

Fields.MenuText: You thinking sabotage?
You thinking some kind of catastrophic collapse?
What are your thoughts?

Fields.DialogueText: Can't really see that as an option, no.
It's as good a thought as any.
I'm keeping an open mind.
All right, then - but we need to narrow the issue down, and soon.
We might need a specialist to sort this out eventually, but my snipes can keep it under control for now.
Very good.
*ALARM*
Due respect, Captain - get those boots to the bridge!
@BATTLE
Doesn't have to be this way, Captain, that's all.
Steady as she goes, Chief.
Aye-aye, Captain. Hope you've got enough room on your desk.
*SLAM*
That's all of it. Every scrap of information me and my snipes have on what we found in Lady Zulu's steerage.

Fields.MenuText: Stem to stern?
I see you left nothing out.
Did you throw in a few extra Bibles for weight?

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, that.
You did ask for a full report.
Nah, wouldn't have been fair to the Bibles....
Right. Well, it's probably worse than it looks.
Let's see what we've got here. Just need a moment to flip through these...
Oh!
What you've managed to repair... Chief, it's downright amazing.
You really think so?
From what I can see, you managed to put Humpty Dumpty back together again!
We, uh... we just...
We...
Aw, quit tryin' to make me blush, Cap! Damn! Hard enough to keep a dry eye watchin' my snipes pull off a miracle, but making an impression on the skipper is--
Just accept my appreciation for a job well done. Plus, I'll let HQ know they've got nothing to worry about.
Get these technical manuals back to the engine room, and we'll get back to the Morganas.
*ALARM*
Guess the Morganas got back to us!
@BATTLE
Cup of tea, Captain? The cooks put a kettle on for me, and I thought you might like some, too.
Was it so obvious that I needed some? Was I looking tired?
I wouldn't put it that way. Just a hunch, is all.
Thanks, Zulu.
If you're hoping for a full English breakfast to go with that tea, keep waiting. The cooks are still struggling to get it right.
I shouldn't be surprised, but I think you've got higher standards for this stuff than a good half of our crewmembers from London or Manchester.
What can I say? I love bangers and mash every bit as much as a good phuthu.

Fields.MenuText: Phuthu? Sounds delicious.
Bangers and mash would be so good right now!
Did you catch a cold? I might have a handkerchief on me...

Fields.DialogueText: A corn-based porridge. Never tried it? You'd probably love it!
I can't argue with that!
Quit teasing me! Phuthu is a food, Captain.
Combining cultures leads to wonderful food, in my opinion. English grease and Zulu corn would make a wonderful meal.
Enough talk about food! We've got a tactics meeting soon, and I don't want everybody to hear my stomach rumbling.
Can't be helped, Captain. Ever since Chief--
*ALARM*
Let's work up a real appetite by kicking some Morganas in their rudders, shall we?
I hope my guns can rumble louder than your stomach!
@BATTLE
Smell that, Captain?
I don't smell anyth--
Stand right here and sniff. What is that? Think the cooks are up to something again?

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't be too alarmed. We've had worse odors on this ship.
Smells worse than their attempt at liver and onions. What are they making?
We've got a grease fire! Sound the alarm!

Fields.DialogueText: Granted - but a strange smell's often the first sign something's wrong. We should investigate, Captain.
I might skip the next meal, Captain.
Aye aye, Captain! I'll--
That smell!
We were just on our way to investigate. Know anything about it? Are they making some kind of traditional Zulu food?
Not exactly...
British cuisine? Italian food?
A French dish?
Each of those guesses is wrong. But also correct. I've had a huge appetite lately, so I ordered the cooks to make me some...
Some what?
Some of everything.
That explains the stench, Captain. Mystery solved.
Stench? You don't find that aroma appetizing? MMM! So hungry! Captain, please don't think me rude if I head to the galley and start eating without waiting for you!
Quite the appetite our Belle's acquired lately.
I suppose that's healthy. No complaints here, but the logistics might start grumbling if Zulu cooks all of our food supplies at once.
*ALARM*
Now there's something really bad for our health, Captain!
Let's go!
@BATTLE
That should do it for the engine room inspection, Zulu. Chief's got things in great shape back here, wouldn't you agree?
I said, Chief's done a great job resolving the last of the grounding damage. Do you agree?
Are you all right? Are you in pain?
*BUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUURP!*
Whew! Not anymore.

Fields.MenuText: Impressive. I can never get my belches to come out that loud.
Big meal?
GACK! That smelled HORRIBLE!

Fields.DialogueText: You just have to project a little bit. Keep practicing and you'll get it!
The biggest!
Oh? I tried my best not to exhale it in your face. Sorry, Captain!
I've had such an appetite lately! I should thank the cooks for indulging me. Chief's repairs plus a few great meals have me feeling normal again.
Glad to see you've made a full recovery, Zulu. I never doubted you were tough enough to pull through.
Thanks, Captain.
And maybe the ship can go back to smelling normal again soon?
*BURP!*
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Flash message, Captain. The radio operator finished decoding it right before you arrived.
Thanks, Lieutenant. I'll take it from here. Briefing in the wardroom in ten minutes.
Oh, great...
HQ's message? What does it say?
If you wondered why we've been encountering so much Morgana harassment on this patrol, HQ has some guesses for us.
Just guesses? I don't hear much confidence, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I never put much faith in HQ's intelligence.
If you expected good news, this report will disappoint you.
I hoped for more, but at least HQ is trying.

Fields.DialogueText: HQ does their best, just like we all do.
HQ doesn't send flash messages just to give destroyers good news.
We'll have to make do with what we have.
HQ sent that message with flash priority, so it must deal with matters of some urgency, right?
Allied intelligence's message confirms that we've attracted heavy Morgana activity, but HQ can't conclusively determine why.
Only that they've taken a keen and disturbing interest in us.
So, HQ predicts we can expect Morganas to keep following us and skirmishing with us out of what? Curiosity? The crew won't react well to that!
For now, we only tell them to expect heavy Morgana activity. And to observe as much detail as possible.
Agreed. We'll likely have to figure this one out for ourselves.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Another priority message from HQ, Captain.
As if that last one wasn't bad enough...
And this one was followed by an acknowledgment from Berlin.
Berlin?
That makes no sense.
It appears the message was shared with Berlin on purpose. HQ's ordering us to coordinate with local German assets.

Fields.MenuText: No need to be apprehensive, Lady Zulu. I'm sure German forces will honor the Zurich Agreement, just as we do.
An excellent opportunity to show our teamwork.
I wonder why HQ has a sudden interest in coordinated operations.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll trust a German not to shoot at us... well....
I'm a Tribal-class destroyer. We're the best at coordinating!
All manner of strange things are coming into play, Captain.
I won't let my guard down for a moment. I won't allow the crew to come to harm.
Thank you, Lieutenant. Get back to the bridge.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Are you all right, Zulu? You're starting to sound a little... paranoid.
I don't like this.  No offence... well, maybe some offence... but I just don't trust the Germans entirely. Not at the national level, anyway.
@BATTLE
Easy, now.
*ALARM*
Morgana contacts coming over the horizon, Captain.
And the German assets?
Still playing nicely.
She'd better. If she deviates from the plan, she's well within range of my guns.
Zurich Agreement, ma'am. When the Morganas are gone for good, THEN we can try to kill each other on the high seas.
I'd like to see her try!

Fields.MenuText: Me, too. How important is the Zurich Agreement, anyway?
Easy on the trigger, Zulu. We can't risk the only treaty that's keeping us allied against the Morganas.
Enough! Follow my orders.

Fields.DialogueText: Ngiyabonga, Captain... but you don't have to tease me. I won't violate the agreement.
I wouldn't dare, Captain – unless that German tries to stab us in the back.
Aye-aye, Captain.
She just took her flags down, Captain... and we have a report from Radio.
The German sub just radioed us her intention to dive before commencing her attack on the Morgana targets.
So we'll just have to trust she does her part? Fine, whatever, as long as she stays out of our way.
Well, we can always count on ourselves.
Agreed.
Flank speed, Zulu. Commence the attack.
@BATTLE
Explain it to me again, Lieutenant. The Germans are working with us...
We're working with each other, actually.
Whatever, Captain. We're all in this together, predators versus prey.
Right.

Fields.MenuText: You're missing the point, Lieutenant.
You're missing the point, sailor.
You two idiots should pay attention to driving the ship.

Fields.DialogueText: Just trying to explain our tactics, Captain.
Been trying my best to make it clear, Captain.
But you said--
Let me explain this to you. Predators attack when their prey looks vulnerable. If we give off signs of vulnerability, or even signs of predictability, then?
Morganas can see it.
And do what with it?
The captain's trying to make the point that careful observation yields critical information.
Well said, Lieutenant.
And I'm observing too much conversation on the bridge. Is that why we're steering seven degrees off the ordered course?
Damn! Sorry, Lady Zulu...
Morganas are watching!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
So much for the temporary alliance with the German submarine. I couldn't see any hits on the Morganas that we didn't inflict ourselves.
Not a trace of her after the fight.
Shall I transmit a request to Berlin for that submarine's after-action report?
Ha! Point taken, Captain... but why are you smiling?
I learned something from that fight.

Fields.MenuText: Even without active Belles, German submarine batteries have much better endurance than I realized.
It took less than a minute for the German submarine to dive before the fight.
Coordinating with a submarine we don't fully trust hindered our attack.

Fields.DialogueText: True! She was under a long time, and didn't surface until she was beyond our visual detection range.
Did you time it?
I didn't want to trip over her torpedoes... if she even fired any to help us out!
Useful enough for me to send back to HQ. I'll include that in my report, along with our usual Morgana information from the fight.
Anything else on your mind, Zulu? Your performance was excellent, as far as I could tell.
I wonder what the Morganas could see. I wonder what they observe and report about us...
Interesting... but don't let curiosity become paranoia, all right?
Agreed.
@BATTLE
Fifty-eight seconds.
Oh? I've seen them dive in as little as thirty. They were holding back.
*ALARM*
Left ten degrees rudder. Steady on one-three-five.
Another course change...
I ordered left ten degrees rudder, Helm. Steady on one-three-five!
One-three-five, aye, ma'am. Steady on course...
You had something else to say?
How did--?
Your posture. I could tell you were thinking something, so why not ask?
It crossed my mind to say that... we're making some strange course changes.
Ah.

Fields.MenuText: Zulu's trying to remain unpredictable.
You should have followed the order the first time. Don't make her repeat herself.
Zulu read you like a book!

Fields.DialogueText: A bit of random behavior spoils a hunter's aim.
Thank you, Captain. A situation like this should not require the Captain to get involved.
And not a particularly challenging book.
That's enough. Calm down, all of you. Keep it professional.
Oh, I was just thinking...
*WHOOSH*
Whoa! My rudder! We're heeling over to starboard, Captain!
Don't panic. I just gave it a nudge.
I'll trust you have a good reason...
There. Have a look.
Oh! Dark smoke coming up, over the horizon? Those are...
Morganas, firing up their engines to flank speed to pursue us.
Right. Thanks for the nudge, then.
@BATTLE
Aren't we the hunters?
Hey!
*ALARM*
Zulu, I just had a conversation with a thoroughly unhappy supply officer. The cooks are cursing your name, apparently.
Hardly surprising, considering how often I criticize their every attempt to make decent liver and onions for supper.
Something new this time! Heeling us over with your dramatic turns made a huge mess in the galley.
My sympathies - I don't like wasting food or people's time - but the maneuver was valuable. You saw what happened, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: We executed a high-speed turn, before going to battle stations. That surprised the crew.
When you suddenly turned, Morganas thought you had spotted them.
You splattered some awful food onto the galley bulkheads, saving us all from certain indigestion. And maybe food poisoning.

Fields.DialogueText: I was more interested in surprising any Morganas in the area, and I was right!
Exactly! We flushed them out.
HA! A side effect, but an unintentional one, I promise.
Operating with that German submarine, I imagined that I might be in her crosshairs. Well, not crosshairs, exactly... but in a firing solution for one of her torpedoes.
Hard, random maneuvers would spoil their ability to line up a shot.
True. It's hard to score a torpedo hit on a maneuvering target. You have to lead the shot, so a target on a steady course and speed is ideal.
Exactly! I felt the Morganas might be watching me, and wanted to spoil their aim...
Then they blundered, revealing themselves by accelerating to keep up with us.
Right.
I like that you're thinking... but go apologize to the cooks.
Perhaps I should wait until after the next battle? Just in case?
... Is the next battle imminent?
You should see them in a few seconds.
Yeah, fair enough.
@BATTLE
Zulu, did your typewriter ribbon finally run out of ink? I didn't think you'd ever stop clacking away in your cabin.
Pardon the noise! I just finished our situation report for this sector of our patrol.
Nice initiative, Zulu... but premature. You can't possibly finish a sector report until--
Until we finish the patrol?
Exactly. What if something else happens right before we finish?
I'm counting on it, actually.
Oh?
I left a few pages blank at the end. I'll fill those in when the Morganas attack us.

Fields.MenuText: Ha! Well, as long as there's a plan!
Your caution has moved beyond paranoia. Now you're... fatalistic.
Morganas are attacking soon? That's nice. Do we have time for a cup of tea first?

Fields.DialogueText: Well... they will attack. They've seen enough of our patrols to figure out the patterns by now.
Don't call me delusional! The Morganas are going to attack – it's a fact!
Probably not.
Perhaps it helps me to imagine Morganas as beasts, if only to ease my mind as we hunt them... but intelligent animals watch and learn.
And you're saying they've observed us enough to anticipate our routes?
I expect so. In fact, we should be arriving at the coordinates for the--
*ALARM*
Damn!
@BATTLE
That's it! What hope is there?! No matter where we go, bang! Morganas!
Our movements are predictable, Lieutenant. Morganas observe and capitalise.
And the more we show them, the more they learn... How do we get away?

Fields.MenuText: We have our orders to complete our patrol. We are NOT going to abandon our mission.
Get a hold of yourself, Lieutenant!
Maybe we need more random maneuvers, to throw them off our trail.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, I... I wasn't suggesting we abandon our patrol.
Aye-aye, Captain.
We've tried, Captain. Zigzags and sudden speed changes are only short-term solutions.
Morganas have carefully observed us enough to predict the overall pattern of our movement through the sea.
We've got to find an advantage here. A way to turn this around.
Wish I could find one, Lady Zulu.
Yeba nesibindi, Lieutenant. Stay brave, and we will find a way.
Doing my best, ma'am. Oh, damn...
I sense it, too.
Would one of you make a proper report?
Contacts on the horizon, Captain. Bearing two-seven-zero.
Morganas to the west!
@BATTLE
Yebo, Lieutenant! Don't lose your courage so easily!
A bit of tea might help. Make some room on your desk, Captain.
Thanks, Zulu. You might find some room if you push those messages from HQ out of the way.
Messages from HQ? What do they say?
They want to pull us off the patrol.
Cha! I was hoping they wouldn't arrive at that conclusion. We've worked so hard!
Time for full disclosure, Zulu. I sent a summary to HQ about our patrol. Morgana engagements, coordinated ops with a German sub, your careful observations...
Those insights were a collaborative effort.
I wonder... is it just me, or are the Morganas taking an undue interest in us?
Us, or our patrol route?
Six of one, half a dozen of the other. To eliminate the possibility that the Morganas are after us in particular, they're pulling us into port. It's a logical move.

Fields.MenuText: It would eliminate a possibility.
It would keep us safe. Let somebody else deal with the problem for a while.
We need a way to exploit the Morgana behavior, not run away from it.

Fields.DialogueText: The logic is hard to deny, but it feels wrong to me.
But then somebody else will become the next target. We can't accept that!
Yebo! Exactly! But how?
Can we turn this to our advantage?
I... I might have an idea. Make some room at your desk, and let me write something down!
Grab that chair and sit right next to me. This desk is big enough for two.
Ngiyabonga, Captain... I... I like working side by side with you.
Lady Zulu was in your cabin for a while, Captain. What were you working on?
She did most of the work. I'll let her explain it.
Morganas absorb all of the information we reveal. Our course, speed, and intentions.
Like hoovering a living room rug. They don't miss a thing!
Exactly, but they do more than observe. They also act. Have a look at the notes I added to the navigation charts, Lieutenant.
What are these lines, Lady Zulu?
At different parts of our patrol area, we encountered Morgana attacks from different directions. By putting them together on the chart, I noticed they were not random.
Nice work, Zulu. I see where this is going.
I still don't see it...

Fields.MenuText: The Morgana forces are coming from specific rally points.
I can clearly see... that Zulu is insane. Call the ship's doctor to the bridge, please.
Actually, I'm not sure I get it yet, either. Keep going, Zulu.

Fields.DialogueText: Yebo! Precisely, Captain!
Cha! I'm serious, Captain! Let me explain!
Aye aye, Captain. Follow my explanation, ngiyabonga.
Morganas are dispatched from specific zones, to intercept us along the shortest possible route.
At first, I couldn't prove it... but then I noticed that the defeated Morganas retreat along the same corresponding vectors.
And where these lines of approach and retreat all intersect...
It's a map of Morgana staging areas in the area! So we maximize our distance from those spots, and we avoid--
We provoke them and anticipate exactly how they will react.
So we can do to them what they've been doing to us?
We can control them.
But we still end up in a fight. What does this really mean?
It means I need to send another message to HQ.
And it also means we can expect Morganas to harass us... right about...
Now.
*ALARM*
Battle stations, Lieutenant!
@BATTLE
What?
I'll explain, Lieutenant.
Is it true? Did HQ cancel our orders to return to port?
That's the message I'm holding in my hands right now. Have a look.
Okukhulu, Captain! Superb! I feel like dancing right now! Tell me about the rest.  I'm too excited to read it.
HQ wants us to... resume our patrol. Act normal. Continue as though nothing has changed.
What? "Act normal?!"

Fields.MenuText: Makes sense. If HQ has a plan brewing, we don't want to alert the Morganas to what's coming.
I agree. Repeating the same behavior is insanity!
Settle down, Zulu. There's more to the message.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose, but what exactly IS coming?
Let me see the message again. There must be more to this...
Yebo. Let's keep reading.
Here it is, near the end of the message. HQ expects us to deal with Morgana forces as usual...
Blast them full of holes and send them away? I can certainly handle that, but then what?
... because HQ is preparing task forces to assault the retreating Morganas. Thanks to your work, Zulu, HQ knows exactly where they're going.
So, we drive the patrol route, and the Morganas leave the closest rally point to attack us. That leaves the rally point vacant.
In theory.
We defeat them, drive them back... and then HQ has a task force waiting at the rally point to smash them when they come limping home!
Ambush weakened Morganas with concentrated, overwhelming force... maybe this is how we sink some of them for good.
Oh...
I see your hand shaking. Are you excited?
Yebo... I... I am, Captain...
Act normal. Even in front of the crew. This message is a secret between you and me.
Aye-aye, Captain. If the crew is unaware, their behavior cannot give anything away.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Everything is normal. Act normal. Normal... Normal, normal, normal.
Orders to the helm?
I did not give you an order, Helm. I was... talking to myself.
Oh. That's not strange at all...
Zulu! Could I talk to you for a moment?
Yebo, Captain. Normal, Captain. Talking in private to the captain. Normal.

Fields.MenuText: This is actually really charming, but you need to get it under control.
You're terrible at keeping secrets, aren't you?
I don't think that sailor suspects a thing. Good work!

Fields.DialogueText: I know, I know. I'm just too excited, Captain!
Cha!
No need to be sarcastic, Captain...
I can't help it! It's like playing hide-and-seek with my sisters... I want to giggle, or... dance, or...
SHOUT!
Orders to the helm?
Nothing, Helm!
If it helps to sober you up, remember that Morganas are absorbing information about everything we do, taking it all in...
Yebo, yebo...
Ha! Imagine a Morgana hoovering her living room. Unable to help herself, just... hoovering the floors over and over again...
Get a hold of yourself, Zulu. Please.
Ahem. Sorry, Captain. I'll keep it together, I promise.
@BATTLE
I know... I'm rubbish at this.
*ALARM*
Ready, Captain...
... and the engine room's ready to answer all bells, Cap...
... and I just washed my uniform, Captain. I'm ready for anything.
That's strange...

Fields.MenuText: You all figured out that something's up. Somebody talked.
What are you preparing for? I didn't order this.
I can still smell your uniform. Maybe you should wash it again.

Fields.DialogueText: Nobody talked, Captain. I promise!
We sensed something was up.
You heard the captain! Get a watch relief and wash your clothes again!
We just... saw how you and Lady Zulu were acting.
We could all smell it, Cap - sure as I can smell a burnt up motor. And, eh, I ain't talkin' about no uniforms, neither.
We have a mission from HQ...
I knew it!
But our mission is to hold the course. We continue our patrol and behave as though nothing has changed. Anything else might ruin HQ's chances at a major victory.
That's all these ears needed, Cap. I'll get back to my snipes, with yer permission.
Dismissed, Chief. Thanks.
Zulu?
According to my charts, we're approaching another intercept line! Expect a heavy Morgana assault to arrive any minute now.
Very well, Zulu.
I'm proud of you all, and Chief, too. I only ask that you do one thing right now. When the Morganas arrive, hit them as hard as we can.
Send them right back from whence they came!
Aye-aye, Captain!
I just hope our behavior hasn't spooked them...
@BATTLE
Belay that order. We need to talk about what's going on here.
*ALARM*
Cup of tea? Needed to stretch my legs, and I felt like having tea with somebody.
Thanks, Zulu. Thoughtful of you, as always, to bring some to my cabin.
*sigh*
Okay. So what's wrong?
I'm just disappointed. When we sent those busted Morganas back to their rally point, I'd hoped HQ's follow-up ambush would have gotten rid of them for good.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah. But, listen, they're thinner in these waters now, and the locals have room to fortify and resupply. It's a significant win.
We'll find a way to kill a Morgana for good... someday.
If we were part of the ambush task force, maybe we could have done it.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm trying to accept that, Captain.
I hope you're right.
I'm not sure of that, but I would have liked to try.
You've got something else on your mind, too.
Oh?!
I'm right, aren't I?
Yebo. You are. How can you tell?
I observe. When I watch you, I notice little things.
Haha! A filthy Morgana spy tactic!
Guilty as charged, Zulu.
I have closed the cabin door, so we are alone in my interrogation room... Confess! Tell me everything you learned from your spying!
A bit of nervousness at odd times. Your hands would tremble a bit, too.
Oh...
I saw it the most when we worked together at my desk, when you sat close to me.
That was how I figured out...
... my feelings. Yebo. Only recently did I realize them myself.
You are always my captain, but no matter how much I might try to conceal them... I know that I also have other feelings for you, too.
My door is closed, and I still have two chairs at my desk. Maybe we can sit close for a little while, just you and me?
I think I'd like that, Captain. Very much.
Zulu? If you can hear me, I'm about to settle in with a good book and something expensive to drink. If it's a bad time, I'd appreciate a bit of warning.
*ALARM*
... A little bit over the top, but appreciated. Thanks.
@BATTLE
